title: 114_s2040
content: The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" recognizes the threat of international terrorism to the United States and the need to address foreign terrorist organizations raising funds for attacks on the US. It aims to establish liability for aiding and abetting terrorism under US law. The Halberstam v. Welch case provides the legal framework for aiding and abetting and conspiracy liability under chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, in cases involving material support to terrorist organizations. The purpose of this Act is to provide civil litigants injured in terrorist attacks within the United States with access to the court system to pursue claims against those who have supported the responsible organizations. The Act aims to provide civil litigants injured in terrorist attacks with the broadest possible basis to seek relief against those who have provided support to foreign organizations engaging in terrorist activities against the United States. It also addresses the responsibility of foreign states for international terrorism against the United States. Foreign states can be held accountable in US courts for damages caused by international terrorism in the United States, excluding acts of war. This includes physical injury, property damage, or death caused by the foreign state or its officials, employees, or agents. Foreign states can be held accountable in US courts for damages caused by international terrorism in the United States, excluding acts of war. A national of the United States may bring a claim against a foreign state if the foreign state would not be immune under certain conditions. The jurisdiction of US courts over foreign states is limited to intentional acts, not mere negligence. Foreign states can be held accountable in US courts for international terrorism against the United States. Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include aiding and abetting liability for civil actions related to terrorist acts committed by designated foreign terrorist organizations. The amendment to Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, allows liability to be asserted against individuals who aid, abet, or conspire in acts of international terrorism. This amendment does not affect the immunity of foreign states under other laws. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction over actions involving foreign states under section 1605B of title 28. The Attorney General may intervene in such actions. The Attorney General may intervene in actions where a foreign state is under US court jurisdiction for seeking a stay of the civil action. A court may grant a stay for up to 180 days if the Secretary of State certifies ongoing good faith discussions with the foreign state defendant. The Attorney General can request a stay of civil action for up to 180 days, with the possibility of extensions in 180-day increments if good faith discussions with the foreign state defendant continue. If any part of the Act is deemed invalid, the rest remains intact. The Act allows for a stay of civil action for up to 180 days at the request of the Attorney General. If any provision is found invalid, the rest of the Act and its amendments remain unaffected. The amendments apply to civil actions pending or commenced after the enactment date and arising from injuries on or after September 11, 2001.
